newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: PRESS DIGEST - Ireland, May 19.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Ireland, May 19.

text.p: The following are the highlights of stories from the Irish press on Monday.
- Fine Gael, the main government party, has decided to concentrate its 1.5 billion Irish pounds tax reform package on people with middle and low incomes.
- Some of the most severe laws ever drawn up to combat crime in the State have been proposed by an Irish-government appointed group reviewing the operation of the Irish police.

- British government officials and Sinn Fein representatives will meet this week, possibly as early as on Tuesday, in the wake of the authorisation of such a meeting by the British Prime Minister, Tony Blair, on Friday.

- State-owned Irish airports operator Aer Rianta has won its biggest ever overseas contract, to sell spirits and tobacco at 12-duty free shops in Hong Kong's giant new airport which is due to open in April next year, according to industry sources in Hong Kong.
- Ireland's Labour Party is proposing double child benefit payouts for August and December, the two most expensive months of the year for families.
- State-owned Irish airports operator Aer Rianta has landed a 125 million Irish pounds a year contract to run 12 duty free shops at a massive new airport in Hong Kong.
- Anglo Irish Bank is to raise well over 100 million Irish pounds in additional capital through the issue of new preference shares, according to reliable sources.

- The Irish government on Sunday scotched opposition claims that the main government party had gone behind the backs of its coalition partners with a 1.5 billion Irish pounds tax package unveiled without the support of the Labour Party or the Democratic Left.
